title-part.text: SPEECH OR AUDIO CODING OR DECODING

note.note-paragraph: This subclass does not cover: devices for the storage of speech signals, which are covered by subclasses G11B and G11C; encoding of compressed speech signals for transmission or storage, which is covered by group H03M7/30.

title-part.text: Generation of natural phrases from machine-based concepts

reference.text: generation of parameters for speech synthesis out of text G10L13/08

title-part.text: Voice editing, e.g. manipulating the voice of the synthesiser
Details of speech synthesis systems, e.g. synthesiser structure or memory management

CPC-specific-text.text: Synthesisers specially adapted to particular applications

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L13/00 and subgroups.

title-part.text: Elementary speech units used in speech synthesisers
Text analysis or generation of parameters for speech synthesis out of text, e.g. grapheme to phoneme translation, prosody generation or stress or intonation determination
Assessment or evaluation of speech recognition systems
Training of speech recognition systems, e.g. adaptation to the characteristics of the speaker's voice
using distance or distortion measures between unknown speech and reference templates
using dynamic programming techniques, e.g. dynamic time warping [DTW]
using statistical models, e.g. hidden Markov models [HMMs]

CPC-specific-text.text: with insufficient amount of training data, e.g. state sharing, tying, deleted interpolation
Duration modelling in HMMs, e.g. semi HMM, segmental models or transition probabilities
Semantic context, e.g. disambiguation of the recognition hypotheses based on word meaning

title-part.text: using context dependencies, e.g. language models
Phonemic context, e.g. pronunciation rules, phonotactical constraints or phoneme n-grams
Grammatical context, e.g. disambiguation of the recognition hypotheses based on word sequence rules
Formal grammars, e.g. finite state automata, context free grammars or word networks
Speech recognition techniques specially adapted for robustness in adverse environments, e.g. in noise, of stress induced speech
Procedures used during a speech recognition process, e.g. man-machine dialogue

CPC-specific-text.text: Barge in, i.e. overridable guidance for interrupting prompts

title-part.text: using position of the lips, movement of the lips or face analysis

CPC-specific-text.text: Speech recognisers specially adapted for particular applications

reference.text: devices for signalling identity of wanted subscriber in a telephonic communication equipment controlled by voice recognition H04M1/271; speech interaction details in interactive information services in a telephonic communication system H04M3/4936

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L15/00 and subgroups.

title-part.text: Constructional details of speech recognition systems

CPC-specific-text.text: Memory allocation or algorithm optimisation to reduce hardware requirements

title-part.text: Distributed recognition, e.g. in client-server systems, for mobile phones or network applications
Multiple recognisers used in sequence or in parallel
Score combination systems therefor, e.g. voting systems
Adaptation of a single recogniser for parallel processing, e.g. by use of multiple processors or cloud computing

CPC-specific-text.text: Speaker recognisers specially adapted for particular applications

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L17/00 and subgroups.

title-part.text: Pattern representation or modelling, e.g. based on linear discriminant analysis [LDA] or principal components
Use of distortion metrics or a particular distance between probe pattern and reference templates
Multimodal systems, i.e. based on the integration of multiple recognition engines or fusion of expert systems
Use of phonemic categorisation or speech recognition prior to speaker recognition or verification
Pattern transformations or operations aimed at increasing system robustness, e.g. against channel noise or different working conditions
the user being prompted to utter a password or a predefined phrase
Recognition of special voice characteristics, e.g. for use in lie detectors
Speech or audio signal analysis-synthesis techniques for redundancy reduction, e.g. in vocoders
Coding or decoding of speech or audio signal, using source filter models or psychoacoustic analysis

CPC-specific-text.text: Lossless audio signal coding; Perfect reconstruction of coded audio signal by transmission of coding error
Speech coding using phonetic or linguistical decoding of the source; Reconstruction using text-to-speech synthesis
Vocoders specially adapted for particular applications

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L19/00 and subgroups.

title-part.text: Correction of errors induced by the transmission channel, if related to the coding algorithm
Multichannel audio signal coding or decoding, i.e. using interchannel correlation to reduce redundancies, e.g. joint-stereo, intensity-coding, matrixing

reference.text: arrangements for reproducing spatial sound H04R5/00; stereophonic systems, e.g. spatial sound capture or matrixing of audio signals in the decoded state H04S

title-part.text: Audio watermarking, i.e. embedding inaudible data in the audio signal
using spectral analysis, e.g. transform vocoders or subband vocoders
Blocking, i.e. grouping of samples in time
Detection of transients or attacks for time/frequency resolution switching
Noise substitution, i.e. substituting non-tonal spectral components by noisy source

reference.text: comfort noise for discontinuous speech transmission G10L19/012

title-part.text: Temporary noise shaping [TNS], e.g. in MPEG2 or MPEG4
Quantisation or dequantisation of spectral components
Determination or coding of the spectral characteristics, e.g. of the short-term prediction coefficients
Determination or coding of the excitation function
Determination or coding of the long-term prediction parameters
the excitation function being an excitation gain
using mixed excitation models, e.g. MELP, MBE, split band LPC or HVXC
Long term prediction, i.e. removing periodical redundancies, e.g. by using adaptive codebook or pitch predictor
using prototype waveform decomposition or prototype waveform interpolative [PWI] coders
the excitation function being a multipulse excitation
Sparse pulse excitation, e.g. by using algebraic codebook
the excitation function being a code excitation, e.g. in code excited linear prediction [CELP] vocoders
Pitch excitation, e.g. pitch synchronous innovation CELP [PSI-CELP]

CPC-specific-text.text: Audio streaming, i.e. formatting and decoding of an encoded audio signal representation into a data stream for transmission or storage purposes
Transcoding, i.e. converting between two coded representations avoiding cascaded coding-decoding

title-part.text: using sound class specific coding, hybrid encoders or object based coding
Mode decision, i.e. based on audio signal content versus external parameters
Variable rate codecs, e.g. for generating different qualities using a scalable representation such as hierarchical encoding or layered encoding

CPC-specific-text.text: Pre-filtering, e.g. high frequency emphasis prior to encoding

title-part.text: Processing of the speech or voice signal to produce another audible or non-audible signal, e.g. visual or tactile, in order to modify its quality or its intelligibility
Changing voice quality, e.g. pitch or formants
Speech enhancement, e.g. noise reduction or echo cancellation

reference.text: reducing echo effects in line transmission systems H04B3/20 ; echo suppression in hands-free telephones H04M9/08

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L21/00 and subgroups.

CPC-specific-text.text: Enhancement of intelligibility of clean or coded speech

note.note-paragraph: This group is no longer used for the classification of new documents as from September 1, 2012. The backlog is being reclassified to G10L21/0364, G10L21/057.

title-part.text: characterised by the method used for estimating noise
characterised by the type of parameter measurement, e.g. correlation techniques, zero crossing techniques or predictive techniques
characterised by the type of parameter measurement, e.g. correlation techniques, zero crossing techniques or predictive techniques
for synchronising with other signals, e.g. video signals
using thinning out or insertion of a waveform
characterised by the type of waveform to be thinned out or inserted
characterised by the interconnection of waveforms
for synchronising with other signals, e.g. video signals
Transformation of speech into a non-audible representation, e.g. speech visualisation or speech processing for tactile aids

reference.text: devices or methods enabling ear patients to replace direct auditory perception by another kind of perception A61F11/04

title-part.text: Speech or voice analysis techniques not restricted to a single one of groups G10L15/00-G10L21/00
characterised by the type of extracted parameters
the extracted parameters being correlation coefficients
the extracted parameters being zero crossing rates
the extracted parameters being prediction coefficients
the extracted parameters being formant information
the extracted parameters being spectral information of each sub-band
the extracted parameters being power information
the extracted parameters being the cepstrum
characterised by the type of analysis window
for measuring the quality of voice signals
for extracting parameters related to health condition

title-part.text: for evaluating synthetic or decoded voice signals
Detection of presence or absence of voice signals

Discriminating between voiced and unvoiced parts of speech signals
Subject matter not provided for in other groups of this subclass
Text analysis or generation of parameters for speech synthesis out of text, e.g. grapheme to phoneme translation, prosody generation or stress or intonation determination

CPC-specific-text.text: Demisyllables, biphones or triphones being the recognition units
Phonemes, fenemes or fenones being the recognition units

title-part.text: Training of speech recognition systems, e.g. adaptation to the characteristics of the speaker's voice

updating or merging of old and new templates; Mean values; Weighting
Search algorithms, e.g. Baum-Welch or Viterbi
Methods for reducing search complexity, pruning

title-part.text: Procedures used during a speech recognition process, e.g. man-machine dialogue
Execution procedure of a spoken command
Speech or audio signal analysis-synthesis techniques for redundancy reduction, e.g. in vocoders
Coding or decoding of speech or audio signal, using source filter models or psychoacoustic analysis

CPC-specific-text.text: Design or structure of the codebook
Tree or treillis structures; Delayed decisions
Long term prediction filters, i.e. pitch estimation
Smoothing of parameters of the decoder interpolation

title-part.text: Processing of the speech or voice signal to produce another audible or non-audible signal, e.g. visual or tactile, in order to modify its quality or its intelligibility
Changing voice quality, e.g. pitch or formants
Speech enhancement, e.g. noise reduction or echo cancellation

the noise being separate speech, e.g. cocktail party

Two microphones, one receiving mainly the noise signal and the other one mainly the speech signal
the estimation exclusively taking place during speech pauses
Aids for the handicapped in speaking

Synthesis of the lips movements from speech, e.g. for talking heads
